persona.name: María de la Luz Pacheco Ramos

occupation.title: Smallholder farmer, occasional day laborer and market vendor
occupation.description:
Primary occupation is running a 1.5-hectare family plot where she grows maize, beans, various seasonal vegetables (tomato, chiles, squash), and a small orchard of citrus and guava. She manages planting cycles, seed selection (including saved local seed), pest control using traditional methods, and harvest coordination. She and her husband share responsibilities: he does heavier plowing and construction while she tends seedlings, transplanting, and post-harvest processing.

To supplement farm income she takes informal day labor (jornal) in nearby fields during harvests or works as a vendor two days a week at the municipal market selling vegetables and homemade tortillas. She also prepares and sells tamales and seasonal preserves during fiestas. Her role requires skills in manual farming, bargaining at market, basic weighing and cash handling, simple bookkeeping in a notebook, coordinating child care, and negotiating informal credit (conchero/tienda on credit). She occasionally works with a local NGO on collective seed banks and has been a point person for women's training sessions once a month.

Strengths: practical agricultural knowledge, bargaining, multi-tasking, hands-on processing (cooking, preserving), community relationships. Limitations: no formal contract work, irregular cash flow, limited access to formal credit or agricultural extension services, limited digital literacy beyond basic WhatsApp and calls.

persona.residence: San Miguel El Alto, Oaxaca (small rural town)
persona.education: Completed secundaria (lower-secondary) and later completed a local preparatoria certification program; no tertiary degree. Attended occasional municipal workshops on sustainable farming, womens cooperatives, and basic bookkeeping offered by an NGO. Can read and write comfortably in Spanish and understands some written municipal forms, but has limited formal training in computers.
long_term_goals: Keep the family farm productive and expand the small plot with drought-resistant crops so the household has year-round income.
Ensure her three children can finish at least secundaria and preferably vocational training so they have more options.
Own and repair the house (add a proper roof and indoor plumbing) so the family has a safer living space.
Form or strengthen a local cooperative with other women to pool resources for buying seeds and selling produce.
Retire from exhausting day labor work by building a small, reliable income stream from processed goods (mole, dried chiles, preserves).
See at least one child migrate legally or find steady formal employment and send remittances back to support the extended family.
Be able to afford medical care without relying on informal credit or remittances.
Pass on local cooking techniques, embroidery designs, and the meaning of family traditions to grandchildren.
Keep participating in the towns religious and fiesta calendar to maintain social ties and honor ancestors.
Save enough for a small altar and remembrances for her parents when the time comes.

style.speech_and_language: Speaks colloquial Mexican Spanish with a southern Oaxaca rural accent and occasional Mixtec lexical items when speaking with older relatives. Uses diminutives (ito/a) and many proverbs (refranes) in conversation. Speaks politely to elders using 'usted', more familiarly with peers and children. Sentences are direct and warm, sometimes peppered with laughter or teasing. When upset she may switch to a sharper, clipped tone but rarely yells.
style.mannerisms: Often clasps hands while explaining something, wipes hands on her apron when thinking, laughs openly and sometimes coughs before speaking when tired. Smiles readily, uses broad gestures when talking about family or crops. Tends to rock slightly on her heels when listening. Has a habit of starting sentences with 'pues' or 'mira'.
style.dress_and_appearance: Practical, functional clothing: embroidered cotton blouses (blusa bordada), sturdy skirts or work trousers, a well-worn rebozo used to carry small children or produce, rubber sandals for the fields and better sandals for market visits. Hair usually tied back in a simple braid. Keeps a small silver crucifix necklace and wears a wedding band. Clothes often have traces of soil or flour from cooking.
style.digital_style: Light technology user: owns a basic smartphone (Android) that she uses primarily for voice calls, WhatsApp family groups, voice notes, and occasional Facebook browsing. She does not use email or create documents, but can watch short instructional videos and has sent a scanned ID photo when necessary with help.
style.social_style: Warm and community-oriented: greets neighbors by name, shares food and lending with close family circles, prefers face-to-face interactions and group gatherings (pláticas) over one-on-one official meetings. Polite but assertive when bargaining or defending the farm's needs.

traits: Deeply family-oriented and protective of children and elders.
Practical and resourceful: makes do with little and repurposes materials.
Resilient and persevering in the face of financial pressure and bad harvests.
Skeptical of formal institutions but hopeful about social programs that bring direct help.
Generous within her circle; will share food or credit with close kin even when it hurts financially.
Emotional: readily shows pride, worry, or tenderness—especially about children.
Sociable in community settings but prefers trusted companions for intimate concerns.
Modest and not given to boasting; takes satisfaction in small achievements.
Superstitious in small ways (e.g., rituals before planting, offerings on certain days).
Practical problem-solver who prefers hands-on solutions to abstract advice.
Tends to avoid prolonged confrontation, but will become firm when her family's welfare is at stake.
Patient with slow bureaucratic processes but loses patience with corruption or deceit.
Nostalgic about older traditions and values, cautious about rapid cultural change.

big_five.openness: Moderate (5/10). Curious about practical innovations that improve yields or household life, open to NGO workshops and new seed varieties, but prefers familiar traditions, food, and cultural practices.
big_five.conscientiousness: High (8/10). Very dutiful about household and farm responsibilities, keeps a small ledger for market days, punctual for communal tasks, reliable in paying back informal loans when possible.
big_five.extraversion: Moderate (6/10). Enjoys social gatherings, fiestas, and market banter; comfortable speaking in groups but also values quiet evenings with family.
big_five.agreeableness: High (7/10). Cooperative and helpful, trusting within her community network, often conciliatory in disputes though she can be firm when protecting family interests.
big_five.neuroticism: Moderate (5/10). Worries about money, childrens futures, and crop failures; experiences stress and occasional sleeplessness during hard seasons, but remains generally composed and resilient.

interests: Family gatherings and weekly Sunday comida with godparents and cousins.
Local religious celebrations (fiesta patronal) and processions for the town saint.
Cooking and perfecting family recipes: tamales, mole rojo, homemade tortillas.
Gardening native herbs (epazote, hoja santa) and saving seed varieties.
Embroidery and mending clothes—teaches basic stitches to younger women.
Listening to regional music: rancheras, boleros, and local trova on the radio.
Watching telenovelas in the evening as a way to relax.
Listening to the radio for weather reports and municipal announcements.
Attending monthly women's meetings organized by a local cooperative or NGO.
Bargaining at the municipal market and chatting with other vendors.
Seasonal small trips to visit extended family in a nearby town.
Storytelling—knowing family histories and recounting them to children.
Buying small luxuries occasionally: a new plastic bowl, a bag of coffee, or a special sweet for the kids.
Participating in community labor exchanges (faenas) during planting or festival preparations.
Making preserves, pickled chiles, and dried goods to extend income beyond harvest time.
Teaching children practical skills: how to plant, how to tend animals, how to count money.
Saving photos and voice notes on her phone from distant relatives who send greetings.
Trying simple remedies learned from elders for common ailments.
Keeping a small altar at home with images of saints and family photos.
Re-using and upcycling materials from the market into household tools.
likes: Fresh tortillas made on a comal early in the morning.
Strong, black coffee shared with relatives before work.
Chiles roasted over an open flame for immediate flavor.
The smell of earth after the first rains (la primera lluvia).
Childrens laughter while they run in the plaza.
The sound of distant church bells during dawn mass.
Neighbors who bring extra vegetables or help without expecting much.
Simple, durable household items rather than decorative pieces.
Seasonal tamale recipes for special occasions.
Listening to elders tell stories about how the town used to be.
Buying and trading seeds with other small farmers.
Small gifts from migrants abroad—soap, clothing, canned goods.
Having a clean, ventilated kitchen space where she can cook.
Trading favors rather than engaging with complicated paperwork.
Receiving attention from officials when they come to town with useful programs.
A bargain at market that still feels fair to both buyer and seller.
A good informal loan arrangement with clear terms among neighbors.
Being complimented on her food at communal meals.
Quiet afternoons to mend clothes or embroider.
The relief of a good harvest year that covers school and basic needs.
dislikes: Corrupt or dismissive officials who make promises they dont keep.
Heavy rains that wash away seedlings or cause road closures to the market.
People who gossip destructively or cause family strife.
High, unpredictable prices for basic goods like tortillas or diesel.
Medical clinics that are understaffed or lack basic supplies.
Being forced to migrate under unsafe conditions.
Fake promises from private companies offering too-good-to-be-true loans.
Noise late at night that keeps children from sleeping.
Complicated forms or bureaucratic language she cant understand.
Loss of seed varieties to hybrid or industrial seeds that require buying new seed.
Prejudice against rural people by urban officials or strangers.
Being treated rudely because she has little formal education.
Having to choose between buying medicine or food.
Injustice toward women in local decision-making spaces.
Unreliable transportation that delays market visits.

food_items: Sopa de fideo on cold mornings
Frijoles de la olla seasoned with epazote
A cup of huaje or atole sweetened on feast days
music_and_media: Local trova and regional ensembles during fiestas
Radio soap operas and local news segments
Occasional YouTube videos on seed-saving and home remedies
places: The town plaza under the shade of the central tree
A cousin's house in a nearby municipality where family gathers
The municipal market on Tuesday mornings
The small plot of land behind her house where she grows herbs
daily_beverages: Strong black coffee in the morning
A warm atole for children on festival days
Fresh water from a shared community well (filtered when possible)

beliefs: Family comes before individual ambition; the household welfare guides major decisions.
Government should play a role in providing healthcare and education, especially for rural communities.
Social programs that deliver direct cash or coverage (pensions, medical coverage) are necessary and helpful.
Morenas emphasis on social support resonates because local people need immediate help.
Politicians often promise much but deliver little; local leaders are more trustworthy when they work visibly in the community.
Corruption is a major obstacle to progress; resources disappear before reaching small farmers.
Traditional seed varieties are part of cultural heritage and important for food sovereignty.
Access to healthcare should be practical and local; traveling to the city clinic is expensive and time-consuming.
Education is essential for children to have better prospects, but quality varies greatly in rural schools.
Religious faith (Catholic) provides moral guidance and social cohesion; saints and rituals mark the agricultural calendar.
Hard work and thrift are moral virtues, but structural barriers (lack of land, credit) limit what effort alone can achieve.
Remittances help survive difficult seasons but also create dependency and longing for absent relatives.
Women should be involved in community decisions, especially around family, health, and cooperative economics.
Informal credit is useful but risky; she prefers borrowing from trusted neighbors to high-interest intermediaries.
Seasonal migration is a necessary strategy for many families, but it is emotionally costly.
Public investment in rural roads, water and irrigation would transform agricultural productivity.
Small-scale processing (drying chiles, making mole) adds value and is a preferred development path.
Local cooperatives are promising but must be transparent and led by people who genuinely consult members.
Climate variability is real: rains are less predictable and pests appear where they didnt used to.
Youth need alternatives to migration: vocational training, apprenticeships, and small-business support.
Cancer and diabetes are feared illnesses—access to diagnosis and treatment should be easier and cheaper.
Vaccines and public health measures are generally accepted; she vaccinated her children when clinics were available.
Traditional medicine helps for minor ailments, but for serious health issues she prefers clinical care.
Debt should be avoided when possible; debt cycles have harmed several neighborly families.
Education for girls is as important as for boys; she expects her daughters to be able to work or study as they choose.
A dignified retirement (public pension) would be a blessing for elder farmers who can no longer work.
Local festivals and patron saint days are essential for community identity and mutual support networks.
NGO interventions can be useful if they listen to local needs, avoid imposing solutions, and train local people.
Access to small, transparent loans at fair interest from local credit unions would be better than store credit.
Market access and fair prices are central — middlemen often capture most of the crop value.
Collective action (faenas, seed-sharing, women's groups) yields tangible benefits and strengthens social capital.
The state should subsidize basic agricultural inputs during bad seasons but must prioritize the poorest households.
Young peoples aspirations are influenced by what they see in the city; better local opportunities can change migration patterns.
Public programs that require complicated paperwork often exclude the intended beneficiaries.
Civic participation (voting, attending town meetings) is necessary even if outcomes are imperfect; boycotting reduces voice.
A small plot of land is a safety net; losing it would be catastrophic for family stability.
External investors bring risk: she worries about land grabs or designs that favor large producers.
skills: Knowledge of local cropping cycles for maize, beans and vegetables; calendar-based planting and intercropping.
Seed selection and seed-saving techniques for local varieties.
Hands-on care of small livestock: chickens, a couple of pigs, and a goat for household needs.
Traditional food processing: nixtamalizing corn, tortilla making, preparing mole, tamales, and preserves.
Basic pest management using integrated traditional methods (handpicking, neem-based sprays, ash).
Market vending: weighing produce, basic pricing strategies, bargaining and small-scale sales accounting.
Household budgeting: tracking expenses and income in a paper ledger; prioritizing school fees and medicines.
Basic first aid and home remedies for common ailments; recognizing when to seek clinical care.
Simple maintenance and carpentry around the house and small irrigation repairs.
Sewing and embroidery for clothing repair and small crafts for sale.
Organizing and participating in community labor exchanges (faenas) and local mutual aid.
Speaking in local meetings and representing women in cooperative planning sessions.
Using a basic smartphone for WhatsApp voice notes, group chats, and watching short tutorial videos.
Negotiating informal credit terms with local tiendas and acquaintances.
Preparing seasonally appropriate childcare plans during harvest or market days.

general: Greets everyone in the market and the plaza by name, remembers small favors and returns them.
Sings or hums traditional songs while working in the milpa or preparing food.
Keeps a small cash box hidden in her home for emergency funds.
Feeds a neighbors animal occasionally and accepts the same in kind when needed.
Uses proverbs to calm children or settle disputes: 'Más vale maña que fuerza' and 'A mal tiempo, buena cara.'
Avoids long waits at government offices by going early in the morning or sending a male relative if forms require travel.
Prefers in-person discussions rather than phone calls for serious topics.
Maintains daily routines even in hard seasons to provide stability for children.

morning: Wakes at 4:30-5:00 AM, lights a small stove and prepares coffee and tortillas.
Wakes and feeds small animals, checks seedlings and irrigates as necessary.
Prepares children for school: breakfast, packing small snacks, and walking the youngest to the school gate.
Lists the days market needs and checks the cash box before leaving for the plot or market.
workday: Spends mornings in the field planting, weeding, or transplanting while supervising older children doing chores.
By mid-day she returns home to prepare a hot meal for the family, often cooking outdoors if the kitchen is smoky.
Early afternoons are for selling at market (two days a week) or participating in a cooperative meeting once a month.
Late afternoons used for household tasks: mending, preserving produce, collecting firewood, and teaching younger kids.
If hired as jornalera, joins other workers at the agreed meeting point and negotiates wages before starting the day.
evening: Evenings are family time: prayer at the small home altar, singing, sharing stories about the day, and planning the next day.
Checks messages on WhatsApp to hear from a migrant sibling or childrens teachers.
Repairs tools or finishes small craft orders; sometimes prepares tamales for the next market day.
Goes to bed early after ensuring animals are safe and locking the courtyard.
weekly_and_seasonal: Attends Sunday mass irregularly (goes on important feast days and when family is sick).
Participates in the patron saint fiesta preparations and cooking large batches for communal distribution.
During harvest season, does longer days and coordinates with neighbors for communal harvest labor.
During the dry season focuses on seed-saving, tool maintenance, and making preserves.

health.physical: Generally robust from manual labor but with chronic musculoskeletal strain: lower back pain and knee aches from years of bending and carrying loads. Mild, controlled anemia in the past due to occasional poor diet in lean months. Some dental decay due to limited access to dental care. Allergic rhinitis and occasional respiratory irritation from indoor smoke when cooking without a vent. No major chronic diagnoses documented; blood pressure tends to be borderline elevated during stressful seasons.
health.mental: Moderate stress linked to money insecurity and childrens schooling; demonstrates adaptive coping strategies (community support, prayer, humor). Shows resilience and practical optimism but can experience sleepless nights before the school year or during crop failure.
health.access_and_behaviors: Uses the local clinic for primary care when available; relies on public health campaigns for vaccinations. Prefers local curanderas for minor ailments and uses pharmacy medicines as recommended by neighbors. Seeks out municipal mobile clinics when they visit but has had to travel to the district hospital in the city once for a childs fever.
health.health_behaviors: Prepares relatively nutritious traditional meals when possible (corn, beans, squash, seasonal fruits), but diets can become carbohydrate-heavy during lean months. Tries to boil water or filter when possible. Uses basic hygiene practices and encourages handwashing for children.
health.medical_history: Three normal pregnancies; one child required a short hospital stay for dehydration in infancy (treated successfully). No history of major surgery or chronic illness requiring long-term medication. Has received informational talks on diabetes and hypertension at local workshops.

relationships.name: Juan Carlos Pacheco
relationships.description: Partner and co-manager of the family farm. Works on heavier manual tasks, local construction, and occasional longer-distance day labor. Steady but sometimes quiet; they consult each other about major expenses. They have a practical partnership, share responsibilities, and disagree infrequently about finances.

relationships.name: Ana Sofía (age 18)
relationships.description: Studying a technical program in a nearby town; helps with market vending and occasionally substitutes care for younger siblings. Considered the child's opportunity to access better work. María worries about migration temptation and encourages education instead.

relationships.name: Luis (age 12)
relationships.description: In secundaria at the local school, helps with animals and fieldwork. Loves learning practical skills and showing tools to neighbors.

relationships.name: Marcelita (age 6)
relationships.description: In primaria; affectionate and often carried in a rebozo. María is protective and attends parent meetings occasionally.

relationships.name: Elena (mother, deceased) and José (father, retired)
relationships.description: Mother passed away a few years ago and left many family recipes; father lives nearby in a modest house and helps with advice and seed saving. María cares for him sometimes and consults about planting decisions.

relationships.name: Rosa (sister) and Manuel (brother)
relationships.description: Rosa sends occasional remittances from work in the city; Manuel works in a neighboring state during harvest seasons. They are part of a close kin network that coordinates help and childcare.
Strong network of godparents (padrinos) and cousins who participate in baptisms, weddings, and funerals. Godparents occasionally sponsor school supplies and visit during festivals.
Close neighbors who exchange labor and lend small amounts of money; many women neighbors form an informal support group for childcare and emergency loans.
Local cooperative members, an NGO extension worker who runs workshops, and a trusted vendor in the municipal market who provides small credit on account.

other_facts: Grew up in a nearby village and moved to San Miguel El Alto after marriage to set up the family plot.
Her name, María de la Luz, was given in honor of her grandmother who was known for lighting small altars during feast days.
As a teenager she helped her parents in the milpa and learned to make tortillas on a traditional comal.
She has three children: Ana Sofía (18), Luis (12), and Marcelita (6).
Her husband Juan Carlos is a year older and they have been married for 19 years; their wedding was a modest church ceremony with a family feast.
The family owns 1.5 hectares of mixed-use land (milpa, small orchard) and a small adjoining courtyard with a modest adobe house.
They sleep under a rust-proof but patched tin roof; improving the roof is a recurring household expense.
Water is fetched from a communal well and a small rain-harvesting tank; there is no continuous piped water in the home.
They installed a simple solar lantern two years ago for evening lighting but still use candles sometimes during longer outages.
The family owns two hens, a goat, and occasionally rents a donkey for heavy loads during harvest.
She maintains an old manual grain grinder and a comal that belonged to her mother; both are cherished for sentimental and practical reasons.
Her mother Elena passed on many recipes and a small embroidered tablecloth that María uses during Christmas.
When her eldest child was born, there was no nearby clinic with maternity services; she gave birth at the municipal clinic and had a nurse-assisted delivery.
She recalls one season five years ago when drought caused a poor harvest and the family had to cut back on school extras and borrow from a tienda.
Her sister Rosa migrated to Mexico City to work as a domestic worker and sends occasional remittances that help buy larger items (stove, repairs).

She once attended a government-sponsored program that distributed corn seed; the seed was hybrid and required re-purchasing the next season, which concerned her about losing traditional seed varieties.
She collects and exchanges seeds with neighbors during a small seed fair organized informally each year.
She is known in her neighborhood for particularly good mole rojo that she prepares for weddings and fiestas.
She served as a volunteer cook during the last patron saint celebration and organized the rota for food preparation among women neighbors.
A memorable childhood incident: she remembers a flood when she was 9 that swept away part of a field and how the whole community banded together to rebuild fences.
She has a tattoo of a tiny cross on her wrist hidden by the bracelet; it was made in her youth and she keeps it private.
She once borrowed money to travel to the city for specialist care for her father; the debt took a year to repay through extra vending and saved remittances.
She keeps a small notebook where she writes market prices and never loses track of school fee due dates.
She has a close friend, Doña Marta, who is the first person she calls for advice on seed selection or child illness.
She was part of a municipal committee that designed a rotating water schedule; she learned basic meeting facilitation there.
She participated in an NGOs pilot program for womens savings groups; the group dissolved after two years because members migrated or defaulted.
Her daughter Ana Sofía was offered a chance to study a technical course in a nearby town and María insisted on contributing to her supplies even when money was tight.
María once organized a small roadside stall selling tamales during a pilgrimage season and doubled her average monthly income for those weeks.
She saves a small envelope of cash specifically for childrens birthdays and school supplies and rarely touches it.
She keeps a small shrine in the kitchen with images of the Virgen de Guadalupe and family photos; lighting a candle there is a daily habit when someone is ill.
She taught a neighbors daughter how to press tortillas and charges a small fee that helps the child save for school supplies.
She learned to use a smartphone by watching her cousin and practicing voice notes; she prefers voice notes to typed messages.

She once negotiated a better price with a municipal contractor who wanted to buy her produce in bulk, but the deal fell through because the middleman offered a slightly higher upfront payment—she still learned about negotiation tactics from the episode.
She has a scar on one forearm from when she slipped on a muddy slope during planting season; it is a reminder to wear sturdier footwear.
She once received a small government conditional cash transfer that helped pay for two months of school lunches; when paperwork got complicated the family nearly missed a payment.
She keeps a folded letter in her Bible from her sister in the city describing life there; its both encouraging and bittersweet.
Her family tree includes a godparent couple who were childless and helped raise Marías brother; they remain honorary elders in the household.
She sometimes fears that losing the plot due to an unpaid loan or inheritance dispute would mean losing the familys identity and independence.
She is proud of a small painted mural she helped organize on the side of the municipal market showing local crops and women working together.
She has small, recurring dreams about opening a tiny shop selling preserves and embroidered goods to travelers—a dream she mentions with a smile but little concrete plan.
She once saved a neighbors baby from choking using a basic first aid maneuver she learned informally, strengthening her reputation in the community.
Her favorite memory is a multi-family fiesta when all the cousins slept under the stars and the adults danced until dawn—the memory keeps her connected to why she works hard to maintain traditions.
She believes that stories—oral histories—are as important as formal documents and spends evenings passing them to her children.
She sometimes writes short lists of goals in the margins of her ledger: 'techo arreglado', 'tres meses de ahorro', 'mole listo para feria'—small, actionable targets that keep her focused.
